channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Aleppo Close to Falling Under Complete Control of Syrian Government
item.media:description: A man fleeing to rebel-held areas of Aleppo, Syria, on Monday, carrying a child with an IV drip.
item.description: Government forces and their allies have squeezed fighters and civilians in rebel-held parts of the city into a sliver of territory, spokesmen said.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: A President Trump Excites, and Worries, Persian Gulf Leaders
item.description: The leaders wonder if President Trump will support Syrian rebels, get tougher with Iran, or increase the American military’s presence in the region.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: ‘A Complete Meltdown of Humanity’: Civilians Die in Fight for Eastern Aleppo
item.media:description: Syrian government forces in the Saleheen neighborhood of eastern Aleppo on Monday.
item.description: The United Nations says pro-government forces in the Syrian city have killed scores, including women and children, some shot in the street as they tried to flee.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and ANNE BARNARD
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Cathedral Bombing in Cairo Leaves Egypt Alarmed, and Its President Scrambling
item.media:description: The body of a Christian woman killed in a bombing at a cathedral on Sunday was carried to a cemetery in Cairo on Monday. The attack was the deadliest in years against Egyptian Christians.
item.description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi moved to reassure Egypt’s Coptic Christians after a bombing at their cathedral in Cairo stirred fears of resurgent Islamist violence.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.category: St Mark's Coptic Orthodox Cathedral (Cairo, Egypt)

item.title: Player’s Harrowing Tale of Sexual Abuse Rocks Soccer in Britain
item.media:description: Andrew Woodward became the first professional soccer player in Britain to go public with his claims of sexual abuse.
item.description: Andrew Woodward said he was raped for years by his coach, Barry Bennell. Mr. Woodward’s decision decades later to go public inspired others to come forward and uncovered a scandal.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: With Success Comes Dissension in Italy’s Five Star Movement
item.media:description: Beppe Grillo, the leader of the populist Five Star Movement, delivering a speech in Turin, Italy, before a referendum that led to the resignation of Prime Minister Matteo Renzi.
item.description: As an anti-establishment party gains in popularity, some members worry that it may be drifting away from its founding ethos and toward one of centralized power.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Mexico Grapples With a Surge in Violence
item.media:description: A funeral on October 2010, at the peak of the bloodshed in Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, for one of 14 young people killed at a birthday party.
item.media:credit: Alejandro Bringas/EFE, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.description: In the first 10 months of this year, there were 17,063 homicide cases in Mexico, the highest 10-month tally since 2012.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: Venezuela’s Government Plays Santa, After Seizing Millions of Toys
item.media:description: Confiscated toys in a warehouse in Caracas, Venezuela, last week.
item.description: A toy distributor is accused of hoarding and price gouging, and the consumer protection agency steps in. But some accuse the government of grandstanding.
item.dc:creator: PATRICIA TORRES and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: India Hobbles Through a Cash Crisis, and Electronic Payments Boom
item.media:description: A book seller in Mumbai displayed a sign indicating that he accepts mobile phone payment technology.
item.description: Millions of Indians are moving toward a cashless economy, fulfilling what Prime Minister Narendra Modi now says was an objective of banning 500- and 1,000-rupee notes.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and HARI KUMAR

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte Criticizes Times Coverage of Philippine Drug Campaign
item.media:description: The body of a man killed by unknown gunmen lay behind a convenience store in Manila.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The office of the president said the article and photographic essay had falsely depicted the country as “the Wild, Wild West.”
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: What in the World: If the Pool Is Warm in Paris, Thank the Washing Machine
item.media:credit: Illustration by Tamara Shopsin; Photos by All for You, Mrnok, via shutterstock
item.description: The city has developed clever ways to reuse excess heat from unconventional sources like household wastewater.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: The Twists and Turns of ‘La Marseillaise’
item.media:description: “La Marseillaise” was played prior to the first period of a New York Rangers game at Madison Square Garden on Nov. 15, 2015, two days after the attacks in Paris at the Bataclan concert hall, a sports stadium and cafes.
item.media:credit: Cal Sport Media, via Associated Press
item.description: Following the deadly attacks in 2015, the French government is seeking to turn the national anthem, often associated with the political right, into a symbol of unity.
item.dc:creator: ALEX MARSHALL

item.title: Record Number of Journalists Jailed in 2016, Press Advocacy Group Says
item.media:description: Opposition politicians in Turkey held copies of Cumhuriyet, the country’s oldest secularist daily newspaper, in October after its offices were raided. At least a dozen of the newspaper’s journalists were detained on accusations of producing propaganda.
item.description: At least 257 journalists were imprisoned worldwide, a third of them in Turkey, the Committee to Protect Journalists said.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: António Guterres, Sworn In as U.N.’s Next Leader, Must Factor Trump Into His Plans
item.description: Donald J. Trump’s election will affect major issues facing António Guterres, including the Syrian war and how to preserve the United Nations’ funding and values.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Rex Tillerson’s Company, Exxon, Has Billions at Stake Over Sanctions on Russia
item.media:description: Rex W. Tillerson has voiced skepticism about sanctions that halted some Exxon Mobil projects in Russia.
item.media:credit: Ben Torres for The New York Times
item.description: Russia’s energy industry could create a blurry line between Mr. Tillerson’s interests as an oilman and the role he will assume as America’s top diplomat.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: A. A. Gill, Who Gleefully Skewered Britain’s Restaurants, Dies at 62
item.media:description: A. A. Gill in 2003. He died of lung cancer, which he described as “a trucker’s gut-buster, gimpy, malevolent, meaty malignancy.”
item.description: As an essayist and cultural critic for The Sunday Times, Mr. Gill laid stylishly malicious waste to superstar chefs, trendy restaurants and food fads.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: The Interpreter: Russia and the U.S. Election: What We Know and Don’t Know
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, has been praised by Donald J. Trump, who has repeatedly promised to realign the United States with Russia.
item.description: A guide to separating fact from rumor and speculation in a swirl of news about Russia’s electoral interference.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: If Donald Trump Pushes on Taiwan, How China Could Push Back
item.media:description: President-elect Donald J. Trump being interviewed by Chris Wallace of “Fox News Sunday” at Trump Tower in New York on Saturday.
item.description: The president-elect has suggested that the “One China” policy could be used as a bargaining chip, but China has some leverage of its own.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Indian Police Arrest 12 Moviegoers Accused of Sitting During Anthem
item.media:description: Moviegoers in New Delhi stood for the national anthem before a screening Dec. 4. A Supreme Court ruling requires viewers to stand respectfully while the anthem is played, unless they are physically unable.
item.description: The arrests follow a Supreme Court ruling last month that the anthem be played before each showing, and that everyone in attendance must stand.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Global Health: British Officials Issue a Report Card on Aid Organizations
item.media:description: A toddler received a vaccination in Haiti in 2010.
item.description: The report praised three well-known nonprofits, but took aim at Unesco’s “weak” organizational strength.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.category: Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization

item.title: Hunt for Missing Marcos Art Seeks to Regain Momentum
item.media:description: Imelda Marcos, shown in her apartment in Manila in 2014, and her husband, Ferdinand E. Marcos, who died in 1989, amassed an art collection possibly worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
item.description: The ouster of the Philippine leader in 1986 set off a global search for a collection worth up to $500 million. But after early success, progress has been slow.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN

item.title: Istanbul Journal: In a Smoky Haze, Turks Cling to Their Cigarettes
item.media:description: Smoking outside a cafe in the neighborhood of Kadikoy in Istanbul this month. Turkey’s efforts to impose restrictions and counteract its reputation as a haven for heavy smoking have had little success.
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.description: Turkey has made strong efforts to counteract its smoking habit, with measures nearly as strict as those in any Western country. But smokers resist.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What Comes After Aleppo Falls?
item.media:description: A poster showing President Bashar al-Assad of Syria inside a government military police office in Aleppo this month.
item.description: After years of bloodletting, one almost welcomes an end to the siege of Aleppo. But what comes next may be worse.
item.dc:creator: FAYSAL ITANI

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How Xi Jinping Can Avoid Becoming a Dictator
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China. No hints of a possible successor have emerged, suggesting that he might seek to extend his tenure.
item.description: The Chinese president’s best option for prolonging his tenure is to overhaul the Communist Party’s system of governance.
item.dc:creator: HO PIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Don’t Caricature Europe’s Court
item.media:description: The European Court of Human Rights, in Strasbourg.
item.description: The European Court of Human Rights is a remarkable success in the international rule of law. Demagogues run it down at great risk.
item.dc:creator: THORBJORN JAGLAND

item.title: Where Even Nightmares Are Classified: Psychiatric Care at Guantánamo
item.media:description: A guard tower at a now-empty detention block at Guantánamo Bay. The prison, where nearly 800 men were held over the years, now has 60 detainees.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Secrecy, mistrust and the shadow of interrogation at the American prison limited doctors’ ability to treat mental illness among detainees.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Postcard From the Hajj: A Pilgrim’s Progress: Checking Mecca Off My Bucket List
item.media:description: “Pilgrims surprised me with their warmth.”
item.description: This reporter’s long-dreamed-of journey to explore the heart of Islam revealed surprises, debunked stereotypes and produced one stunning bird video.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
